Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about the evolution of media as it relates to medical breakthroughs and the role of doctors, researchers, and medical professionals in society.

Gained insight into how media has affected the medical industry, the perception of medical authority, and patient empowerment from the late 1800s to the present. Studied a variety of different medical campaigns throughout history and discussed how media played a role in their success or failure.
Learned about history of media and medicine and how the two are intertwined.
The ability to think about historical themes over a number of decades.
I gained an understanding of how media and medicine, healthcare, and related social movements have evolved over the last two centuries in American history.

It gave me a broad understanding of important events within American history from a different viewpoint. I enjoyed critically examining propaganda, advertisements and television in order to widen my perspective on the changing roles of media and medicine in America.

I learned how to look more critically at pieces of media, especially related to healthcare and medicine. I also learned more about the history of healthcare in the US, which is super important and interesting.
I've learned how to look at posters and evaluate the underlying theme/ movements that led to it.
I gained a better understanding of how huge of an impact the media plays into the medical field and the information that is disturbed to the public.
A comprehensive knowledge of the history of medicine through the perspective of the media lens.
I learned how to read papers about the history of health. I learned about the history of medicine in America.
Awesome material. You learn a lot about the dynamic of media and how it affects the world of medicine.
I learned a lot about parts of American history I had no idea existed. It was a great class with not too much work that introduced us to interesting and important themes.
Very little
This course helped me contextualize my public health knowledge in a historical context.
I learned about historical events in medicine that weren't well known. I also learned a lot about different advertising techniques and what worked/didn't.
I learned a lot about media and medicine in modern America.

Alright listen up folks. So I came into this class just looking for a chill HU credit; and I DID get that. However, this class was actually pretty interesting, beyond just fulfilling a distributional requirement. As the name suggests, you learn about how the media influences the trajectory of medicine, covering topics like health heroes (doctors/scientists as heroes), health as a social issue, stigmatization/destigmatization of various diseases, national healthcare, and mental health from the 1880s to the present. It was honestly a pretty engaging course; the lectures are pretty interesting (and important to attend for the notes). You don't really have to do the readings to do well. Overall an interesting, chill HU credit.
Understanding of the relationship between media and medicine. History of medicine and context of history
Conceptualizing and sequencing historical events.

I learned so much about how the media's portrayal of medicine and medical authorities changed throughout history. You learn about books, plays, advertisements, and movies from the 1880s to today. You also learn a lot about social movements that were tied to medicine.
I learned a lot about how media has influences medicine over the years. Media has played a large role in shaping public opinions surrounding medicine and helping advocate for certain groups.
I learned about the history of the connection between media and medicine in America.
This class was absolutely amazing and has been the most interesting class I have taken at Yale so far.

It was very enlightening to take this class coming from an Economics background and no real knowledge of health or media. The course taught me an immense amount of history in a very engaging manner in lecture and well reinforced in section. I feel more passionate about public health now and feel like I gained a lot of knowledge.
I learned all about how the media has influenced public health perceptions from the 1880s to the present. We learned about TB, HIV, food advertisements, medical breakthroughs in the media, etc.
I learned a lot about how the media has affected medicine in the United States, particularly in terms of its impact on the medical authority of doctors.
This course was very interesting and expressed very relevant information.
Relation of Media and Medicine from 1870s-now
I learned about medicine in the 20th century and how it is seen through the media's lens.
You learn about media affects medicine. A very interesting and unique perspective on medicine.
I learned about how media has influenced, and continues to influence both public health and the public's perception of the medical field.

I learned about medical history and how the media influenced the image of medicine and the medical profession in the eyes of society. Finally, I learned how to clearly and critically analyze images and articles in the context of history and their connection to the present.
I learned a lot about the history of medicine in the media.

I developed a thorough understanding of how media plays a critical role in the communication of health information, and that for much of the American public, the media often serves as the primary source of health information
I learned a lot about the history of medical and public health advertising. Also, quite a lot about the public has perceived medicine over the last 130 years.
I learned how pivotal the media has been in shaping the medical profession and the layman's view of medicine and science, and trust in the medical industry.
How the media has affected medicine from 1880 to the present
Learned a lot about the history of medicine and media.
I learned about the major events in the history of medicine as they relate to the media
I learned about the interplay of media and health by examining the recent history of topics like health care, national epidemics, television portrayals of physicians, and others.
I learned a lot about the history of medicine and it's co-development with the American media since the early 20th century.
I learned a lot of history of media and medicine in America. I learned how to analyze various forms of media and compare them analyzing content, message, source, authorship, and intent.

This class taught be about the relationship between the history of medicine and media. I learned that the medical profession has been involved in media since the beginning, and that it will continue to use media as an important platform.
A comprehensive overview of the ways media and medicine intersected throughout modern American history.

I gained a lot of insight and knowledge regarding 19th and 20th century medical figures and breakthroughs. The course did a great job of continuously drawing on main themes in the lectures so it felt like a very streamlined, cohesive class.

A ton of knowledge about not only the history of medicine in America, but American history more broadly. Someone who wants more knowledge of American history and also wants more context on the place of medicine in society can kill two birds with one stone with this course. I think this course gave me knowledge more so than skills.

The class covers the role of media in health movements beginning in the 1870s. In particular, you discover how the use of media led to the perceived rise and fall of the glorification of the medical profession. This class reinforces the broad American historical timeline since the 1870s, and connects major events to the way the media decided to engage the public and portray the  medical discoveries/establishment. The professors stress the effects of different media tactics, especially, the inadvertent spread of stigma. Professor Berland, a doctor, makes comments on practices that doctors should use with respect to the media. (Not pre-med) I found it most interesting to learn about the ways media campaigns have targeted the public and their effectiveness in selling ideas about certain medicines, or diseases and engaging the public.

A critical look at the history of American medicine; ways to criticize facets of medicine and the failures of American institutions in providing for public health; concerted practice at image analysis
I learned a lot about the evolution of media and medicine in America and how theyve grown hand and hand with one another.

I learned about the way media has influenced the way the public perceives medicine and the changing role of the "medical hero" from the 1880s to the present. This course was pretty comprehensive, covering a diverse range of topics from the anti-tuberculosis crusade to prime-time television to tobacco advertising.

I learned about the history of how the media controlled and shaped the view of medicine, and what kinds of topics were prominent. I also learned how to apply my ideas to a topic of my choosing and how to analyze images.
How to analyze, view, and critique different films

I learned about the relationship between media and medicine and how it has affected both throughout history. I have also learned about this relationship's effect on what we see and hear today in the news.
I learned how to ask questions to my doctors
The power of media in shaping the minds of the public
I learned about the history of medicine in modern America and how that was shaped through media.
good course
History of media and medicine
History of medicine in America through the lens of media and politics.
Prior to this course I had not yet considered the role of media in the social construction of epidemics.  Definitely a super interesting course.
History of medical and public health developments in the United States through a critical media lens
I learned so much about how media has shaped medicine and vice versa. Amazing class overall.

I learned a great deal about the initial development of the relationship between the media and medicine and how that relationship has evolved over the course of American history. The course was very informative but also interesting and engaging. We cycled between viewing images and watching film clips and discussing topics.
Learned how to analyze media pieces, how to write a history paper.
The course covered the various media techniques used over the past 150 years, important medical breakthroughs, eras, and events in America's history.
Learned about history of connection between media and medicine.
This was a very helpful class in giving an overview of the history of the medias relationship with the healthcare field.
I learned about public health and media in America.

I gained a better understanding of how the media's relationship with medicine can, and does, affect our personal relationships with medicine in areas such as healthcare, medication, doctor relationships, and pharmacuetical advertising.
History of medicine
A lot of knowledge about media and medicine in history
Had my first introduction into the world of American medicine and it was a smooth and very fun transition.
Learned so much about campaigns throughout the 20th century!
In this class, I learned about the complex relationship between medical/scientific/health advancements and the media. I got a lot of practice on doing image analysis.
Pretty solid overview of the relation of media and medicine. Helpful visual analysis skills. Honestly pretty enjoyable overall.
All about how media has been used throughout American history. The course was structured thematically and a new topic was discussed each lesson.
writing and studying media and medicine
Learned to evaluate and analyze media in context of medicine.
I learned about the origin of modern medicine.
Learning about health advertising and analyzing media
I learned the history of the media's involvement in the exposure and promotion of all medicine-related ideas and campaigns, along with how past blueprints are used in contemporary times.
I learned about the medias role in shaping public opinions on and expectations of health and disease.
I developed a really good understanding of the history of medicine and how the media acted to promote it.
Analysing printed media and contextualising it with history
Learned about many topics relating to how media affects our perception of medicine, the healthcare system, different diseases, etc.
I learned a lot about history
A plethora of information on how the media and medicine coexist and interacts with each other.
I loved learning not only healthcare background but how it impacts society
Insights into how media plays a role in the portrayal of medicine to the public throughout recent history. Also more practice on researching, organizing, and writing a historical paper.

History 147 taught me how to analyze all forms of media, specifically medical related media, to better understand the message and the purpose of the advertisement within the context of the times. I also gained a deep understanding of the critical role of the media in the medical establishment and health trends and health reform.

By taking this class I learned a lot about the trajectory that medicine had been through in America. The class really opened up my eyes to the specific events that led to the kind of medicine we have today.
The course was eye opening I never thought of any material in a critical way. It was really interesting to see how media influenced medicine and who was effective and how.
I learned about the role that media has in shaping Americans' perceptions and opinions, and I learned how to do media analysis on various kinds of media.
How media influences our perception of medicine and how our reception of the doctor / health system has drastically shifted since the 1880s.
I learned about some movements in American history that I didn't know about before
I gained a lot of insight into how the media has influenced the way that the American public views medical authority.

I learned how to analyze the complicated relationship between medicine and media in America from 1880s to present day. For example, we learned about many famous medical researchers in the late 19th century and early to mid-20th century and how the media depicted their medical breakthroughs during the Golden Age of Medicine.
Knowledge of the modern and historical connection between media and medicine as well as other interesting and relevant discussions in medicine.

I learned so much more about the interconnection between society, history, and medicine than I studied before. I never fully appreciated the role that social constructs and understanding has on what medical investments people make.
I obtained a solid foundational knowledge regarding how media and medicine have influenced each other throughout the 20th century and how this has led to our current situation.
I developed visual analysis skills
media and advertising strategies and how the media plays a significant role in influencing personal and governmental health decisions
I developed a timeline of medical breakthroughs.
A breadth of knowledge about important medical topics starting from the 1880's and extending to today. Also, themes/tropes/methods used in media campaigns to spread awareness
I developed writing skill as well as learned about forces at work in our history and current lives that before, I had not yet considered.
I learned a lot about American medicine and history, and the way these areas were affected by media portrayals.
I loved coming to the lectures of this class. I found the course topics novel and fascinating!
History of the media's portrayals of medicine and how media plays a role in influencing the medical profession.
writing skills, historical analysis

The lectures were interesting for a class with very little workload. There could definitely have been more guidance on the final paper, as there wasn't even a rubric, and all of the requirements were inconsistent across the different TAs.

The material is interesting as are most of the readings. The lectures were split between two professors with a couple of guest lectures. It's sometimes difficult to stay engaged during lecture, but overall the lectures were interesting. The professors had visual images onscreen as well as video clips which helped to break up the talking. I didn't always find section exceptionally useful since we just rehashed what we learned in class and in the readings, but overall I found the class interesting.

Strengths: I found the material itself very engaging, as well as the readings (though sometimes the readings were a bit long). I enjoyed having guest lecturers give perspectives from their own areas of study as well. I think the exams are fair and the paper wasn't long. I found the paper fun because it gave me a lot of range to pick a topic that interested me. My TA in particular was great at helping me engage with the material and asking thought provoking questions that, I felt, helped me see how the topics week to week connected with each other. 

Weaknesses: I think the lectures should be posted online alongside key IDs (people, groups, events, etc.) because the lecturers all talk quite quickly and it's hard to keep up. I do wish there was some kind of prompt for the paper. It's fun to pick your own topic, but it's hard if there are literally no instructions besides your topic having some relation to the interplay between media and medicine.
Lectures were cool, but not a lot of organization as to what to focus on for exams.
The readings were very informative and educational. The lectures were quite boring and often the slides would change before anyone could copy the notes down.
The course is very well taught and the content is all very interesting.

I think the course is well organised and the content is very interesting. However, I would have prefered a more international perspective as a lot of the issues discussed were very relevant all over the world and I think this course could benefit greatly from a more global perspective. Additionally, there was very poor communication to students about what was expected on the midterm, and even worse for the final paper. I received no information until days before the paper was due and am still unsure as to whether or not I did it correctly. Additionally, there was next to no consistency between TFs with regards to the paper (the aim of the paper, structure, content, length, formatting), which caused a lot of confusion among students.

lectures were really interesting, although it was sometimes hard to follow with all that was packed into them such that the points being made were obscured. Also, while the lectures were good it sometimes felt as though the professors were just reading essays to us

The class did a great job of delving into some very tough issues, but I hope that the class could include some info on Indigenous/Tribal healthcare. There was barely any mention of this, and I think a knowledge of Indigenous healthcare is essential to understanding US History in general.

The strength of the course is that it can give the international students the brief overview of the American history. The most fatal flaw/weakness of this class is that the grading is very not consistent among the class. What I mean is, your grade is very dependent on who you are assigned to (TA). This really needs to be improved.
Strengths: extremely interesting topics that came me engaged throughout the whole lecture

Strenghts: It's a gut
Weaknesses: TAs, classmates, it's an HSHM course. The TAs miss the mark by assuming that people in the section actually have any interest in the course. We see you, members of various Yale Athletes, making the trek to Davies and then to section. We know y'all are not really that interested in the material, rather you know (like everyone else) that the class is a gut.

Miserable lecture. Room was hot and felt like there was no engagement. Shaded the awesome material and knowledge from the professors. TA's were fantastic and learned more in 50 minutes of section than I did in 100 minutes of lecture.

Overall, the course was very interesting and I learned a lot. I definitely recommend it.
However, there were some problems with the way the course handled disability and disability rights, for example using person-first language (person with a disability) rather than identity-first language (disabled person) as most disabled people prefer. There were also a lot of missed opportunities to cover the ways disabled people advocate for themselves, rather than focusing on problematic family members (such as Jenny McCarthy, who uses harmful ableist language about her autistic son). A course like this is a perfect opportunity to introduce students to basic disability politics, so it's quite disappointing that the professors didn't take that opportunity.
One of the midterm questions was poorly phrased, and my TF brought up in section that some people had gotten low grades because they hadn't answered it about two different themes. In that case, it was a problem with the question, and we should not have had our grades lowered, especially since it was a widespread enough problem that my TF had to bring it up. If the question was written well I would have answered it the way the instructors wanted.

The course is super engaging without being too much work. Section and readings supplemented the lecture material well. It is tough that they don't post the lecture slides because it can be hard to study for the final and midterm unless you take really good notes throughout the semester.

Some of the lectures were boring. The readings were heavy, and often not very helpful. Sections were the the only opportunity to actively engage with the material. Your grade was composed entirely of a very few number of assignments that was pretty stressful. However, the material was very interesting, and I learned a lot about media and medicine in modern America.
I think the greatest strength is the size of the class. Opportunty for tons of different opinions. Course materials are strong

Strengths: Super interesting and engaging, not a lot of work, the lectures were taught by theme (instead of chronologically) so it made it easy to study for the midterm/final
weakness: bouncing between two professors was a little annoying. I think it's easier to fully engage in the class when you have a connection with one professor
The course is well taught, but lectures are pretty dry. It was helpful that many of the readings were covered in class, and section was also a good way to discuss these readings.

The material was really interesting and I enjoyed a lot of the topics that were covered. Ther could have been a bit more clarification given on the expectations for the exams and how we were supposed to approach the prompts.
It was well taught with interesting lecture topics
This course is amazing.  It has such interesting topics and covers so many things while keeping students engaged.  Section is also great.

Strengths: engaging speakers, engaging content, not too much reading and a diversity of readings.

Weaknesses: none that come to mind, maybe moving some lectures around to be more chronological.
I thought content was very interesting and there was a good balance between notes and videos/media pieces in lecture.

This course could be organized way better. Often there were individual lectures that were so rich and interesting but then the topic would be completely dropped by the next class. We cover so many different ideas and events at the loss of getting into a meaningful discussion on any one topic. There were lectures that, though interesting, felt unnecessary and distracting to the rest of the course material. The class jumps around so much chronologically in a way that feels unnecessary. I feel like this class has so much potential to be so interesting and engaging but lacks an overarching coherent narrative and message that ties all of the lectures together and thus makes the class stronger.

One strength is that this class is interesting without bogging you down in work. This allowed me to better absorb the course material without feeling like I was just trying to memorize materials. One weakness is that some of the lectures don't "matter" in the sense their topics didn't really appear on the midterms or finals. Of course, these topics are still interesting, especially if you are interested in medicine.
The lectures were interesting. Weakness might have been I wish the course was more organized in a chronological order.
I liked that there were 2 lecturers, the lectures were pretty engaging

Strengths: I really enjoy the content of the course. The lectures by both professors were engaging and interesting. The way that the information presented to us was organized facilitated connecting different time periods and events with each other throughout the 20th century. However, since the course contents are not organized chronologically, sometimes it was difficult to piece everything together, but I think section really helped with that. 

Weakness: n/a

Lectures were very interesting. It was hard to study for the exam since the lecture went by very quickly to take good notes and the professors did not post slides or notes. I know this policy was meant to penalize people who didn't come to lecture, but it also made it harder for people who went to every lecture.
Organization was a little weird - would be better if it were taught chronologically instead of jumping around all of the time.
Lectures were great! But, a little ambiguous as to the grading.

Strengths:
- Well organized
- Interesting course material and readings
- TFs were incredibly helpful and interested in the material -- always willing to help the students and meet with them

Weaknesses:
- If a class needed to be missed, it was hard to catch up, as much of the course was related to images and videos shown in class
- I felt as though some of the material excluded major events in medical history (particularly as it  related to African American History)
The strength of the course were the lectures. They were very engaging. Cannot think of any weaknesses

This course was well-organized and structured. All of the topics were fascinating and relevant. However, the guidelines for the final paper and exams were lacking. The course could be improved if example essays and exams were provided. Additionally, the reading workload was very heavy.

I loved the course, but one big weakness is not having access to the lecture slides. The TFs do a good job of review before midterms and finals, but sometimes slides move too quickly and I would have liked to look back at them.
It was so boring. The lecturer wrote an essay that was regurgitated from past years. It was read like an essay and was not interesting whatsoever. I do not recommend this class.
There is no homework. Readings aren't necessary as they are covered in lecture, and section responses are participation

The course is interesting and I think the majority of people who take it like the professors, the TAs, and the material. The problem is there is almost no reason to really engage with the material on a deep level. The weekly reading responses are very easy to do with only reading a couple pages of 2-3 reading, and many people get by fine without attending lecture regularly. Obviously we should be personally motivated to engage with the material, but realistically, Yale students will always prioritize more demanding classes.
amazing class!
Would rather the course have gone chronologically so that it is less confusing

I think that the first midterm was not well structured - there wasnt enough time and the people who received their midterm first had more of it. But overall, I loved the information we learned and found it fascinating. The readings acted as great supplements to class. I wish that section leaders had more of a set plan for section - I felt like some sections discussed some things more in depth than others.

The course covers a lot of material which gives a comprehensive look at the history of media and medicine. However, because of that, material feels superficial at times. I also don't know what the TAs and professors expect of us on our assignments and exams especially. I've done all of the readings and have been engaged in section yet still feel like I can't do well in the class.

The lectures and readings were deeply enriching and presented a unique history of health from the perspective of American media. Archival footage and well-prepared lectures come together to create unique narratives--lectures are presented more like a flowing story than a compilation of facts. Both lecturers and the TAs are knowledgeable and lead insightful discourses. 

Weaknesses of the course were more technical. The lack of guidance ahead of assignments and feedback after essays/examinations proved to be a consistent sticking point. At a certain point, this began to cloud the enjoyable lectures because I felt like I wasn't being taught how to integrate evidence from lectures into successful essays.

Maybe it was needed to deliver the material, but I was constantly confused about how to fit any new information historically into what we had learned thus far. It felt like we were constantly jumping between the 1910s and the 1960s and it was really difficult to follow. It felt like the first half of the course was really boring, but the second was really interesting.

I greatly detested the weakly readings, discussion section, and lack of lecture video/transcripts. Taking notes during lecture was difficult because both lecturers spoke quickly. In addition, it was not clear exactly what we needed to know/memorize from lecture; after having taken the course, I realized that I could have done well in the course without going to lecture or discussion section at all - only a quick overview of important events in media/medicine history and a skim of readings would have been required to take both midterms and write a strong paper.
Strengths were the interesting lecture material and great primary sources. The lecturers were also all great. Sometimes the lecture topics didn't connect and flow as well as they could though.
I thought lectures were very captivating, but section could have been more demanding and engaging.

Main strength: incredibly interesting content
Main weakness: Not too much opportunity to get feedback on writing skills. If you want a lot of feedback on the one paper we write, you'll need to schedule an appointment yourself, probably after the semester is over (we got the papers back after the final exam and I didn't get many comments).
Lectures sometimes seemed to be a little bit all over the place.

I really enjoyed the lectures and the readings. My section was a little subpar with the discussions, but overall great class. I think the film festival class was unnecessary and didn't offer much helpful information.
Lectures were interesting and well delivered!

I think this course did a good job of exposing a lot of the medical injustices that happened in America over time. I think the order in which the information was presented in this class was all over the place and couldve been done chronologically.
This course was extremely repetitive at times and while I was very engaged at the beginning I lost interest very quickly.

Strengths: The topics covered were very interesting and thus the readings were pretty enjoyable. 
Weaknesses: I felt like sometimes lectures could get repetitive and the material could be condensed. The material also jumped back and forth between time periods so it was kind of hard to piece everything together until the very end. The expectations for the midterm/final were also extremely vague.

The strengths are the variety of topics discussed, the smaller sections run by the TFs, and the low workload. The weakness was the way that the review session was run as I found it hard to collect all of the information presented in the slides, and found the ones at the end more useful and wished those were discussed first as they took the examples and placed them under a specific theme.

Taught well
Sometimes lots of information
The lectures were mostly very interesting, and the sections were engaging.
I like the videos
I thought the information was interesting, but you don't get much guidance regarding tests and assignments so it's a little hard to know how to do well on them.
He course is not done chronologically which can make it difficult to think of conceptually at times, but it is done thematically so not sure how there could be a compromise of the two found.
More student involvment

Strength: interesting course contents
Weakness: the organisation is slightly loose; long readings that repeat lecture content
Strengths: reading load wasnt too bad, and all the readings were super applicable to the exams and papers.  I loved that the readings were posted online.
This course would potentially be better if it were organized chronologically

The lecture slides were not available online, which was frustrating. I understand that they are kept offline to encourage students to attend lecture, but there were a number of videos and images that I wish I had been able to access, but could not find by myself.

This class was great!! I really enjoyed it, very engaging and good use of videos throughout each lecture which kept things interesting. Would have appreciated more of a concrete study guide, but with my own lecture notes I felt pretty prepared for the exams. Section was also nice to discuss but it was mostly just reviewing lecture material. It would be an improvement if more sections were offered earlier, so that we weren't left with taking a section that is in the evening.

This course is incredibly interesting if you go to lecture and do the readings, but if you don't then you may be a bit bored at times/you'd miss out on getting the most out of a really interesting class

This course was great! The lectures were amazing, and it was very fair. I know that the professors have to incentivise coming to class, but once I had to leave for an interview and had no way to make up the lecture since slides aren't posted.

This course does a great job of showing that such media attention around medicine is not knew and that many advertising campaigns and media coverage have been long forming an intimate relationship with the medical field.
Good lectures engaging
Lecture. Sections good
A bit more time on the midterm perhaps? Maybe a little more guidance on the paper as well. Teaching is very good however.
Strength is the subject! Weakness is its a little all over the place in organizational areas

The readings in this class are fairly short and very interesting. The lecture topics are all very interesting. And the workload was very manageable: you just had to attend section, do a midterm and a final, and write the final paper.

I think the material after the midterm exam was much more interesting than before the midterm. Since the course doesn't follow chronological order but rather is taught by a lecture on a theme each time, it might be helpful to change it up and make some second half material be covered in the first half.
Sections weren't super helpful, and the readings were far too much and I don't know anyone that actually did them all. Could be useful to cut back on readings if you want students to actually do it.

Strength: interesting lectures, the topic changed each week so it was always engaging.

Weakness: the course taught a lot about different topics but it would be good if these topics were linked more to each other.
Sections could better match course material and concepts
Well taught, engaging lectures. The final paper was a bit unclear, not sure what was expected of us.
It was very interesting and I enjoyed going to class everyday and listening to the lectures.
Smaller lecture size
The dynamic is repetitive and some facts or themes are a little self-explanatory. Some ideas could dig deeper or push further with certain topics.

This course was honestly so repetitive. Studying for midterms and finals was so boring and difficult because the point of each lecture was the same and so drawn out. The professors must reorganize the material so it is in chronological order. It was so confusing having them cover the 1880s, then the 1960s, and then going back into the period between the two. Must be ordered.
Overall good course.
The course was very well structured and easy to follow

Strengths: good comprehensive lecture material, interesting readings
Weaknesses: perhaps wish the course could have been ordered more chronologically?
Lectures can be boring but topics are important and interesting
I loved it but should go in chronological order

I enjoyed the duel professor lecturers: during the week we would be exposed to both the history of such media at a specific time as well as the medical side of what we were talking about, which took a more scientific approach to the material.

A weakness of the course was that the lectures went very fast so it was difficult to take good notes while paying attention and thinking about the material being presented (even having done the readings).
A strength of the course was that the sections were very helpful for engaging with the material. I found that the skills I learned in section helped me engage better with the lectures and my readings. The readings were a good length and provided a foundation for the material in lecture, this was another strength of the course.

The strengths of the course were that the lectures covered a lot of the readings and were quite engaging and informative. The only weakness was that sometimes the expectations for the papers were unclear as there was no set rubric.

The weakness that I experienced in this course was my TF Janine. She did not do a good job explaining what she wanted for the term paper. She also was not open minded. She is saw everything from a certain point of view and did not facilitate discussion but instead section was run that her opinion was right.

It has a good overview of the relationship between media and medicine in the last 100ish years. I thought there was a good amount of media incorporated into the lectures and sections - seeing the examples was really helpful. Some of the readings seemed a little unnecessary, they either didn't super relate to what we talked about in section or just repeated some of the other readings. Overall though I liked the readings a lot. I also would have liked a different way of organizing the course. It was organized thematically, but the themes weren't organized chronologically at all, so it felt like we were jumping around a lot.

Strengths- interesting, good lecturers

Weaknesses- sometimes unorganized content in lectures but overall really
Great

The strengths of this course are its excellent professors, one of which (Dr. Berland) is actually a practicing physician, as well as the historical media examples presented in class, including films from the 1930s and 1940s and advertisements dating from 1920 to present day.
One strength was that there were many interesting themes and topics throughout the course that kept the students interested for the duration of the semester.
Strength: passion of professors, depth of topics covered, breadth of topics covered
The lectures were great, I just wish they were published on Canvas because sometimes the pace of each lecture was a bit fast. Really enjoyed the videos and primary sources shown in class.
nothing, it was a good class
Dual professor format was very helpful, media images/videos were engaging
I am not the best analyzer of primary sources. I could use the resources to help me more.

Strengths: Bredth of knowledge
Weaknesses: Powerpoint lectures in class looked like they were put together last minute. Professors read so much from their notes that it was often times difficult to distinguish what was important seeing as we would discuss one or two topics for the entire period.
Also, a timeline at the beginning of the course, similar to the one given during the review guide would have been tremendously helpful.
The course could be improved by permitting students to access the lecture slideshow for learning and studying purposes.

I think the course material itself was very interesting and I felt very engaged. However, no slides or lecture material were posted online  I think it would be helpful to post the images and clips from lecture, so students can rewatch them when studying.
I didn't find section particularly useful. Perhaps a smaller class size for section would help make the discussions more meaningful.

I enjoyed section and the topics discussed in this course. Sometimes we would jump around to different time periods which was a little confusing; if we went in chronological order it would have made more sense.
extra credit availability would've been nice

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants an interesting 4th/5th class with not a lot of work. The paper is a little difficult, and the midterm/final can be graded harshly depending on your TA, but the course is pretty engaging and not too hard.

I would recommend it to anyone interested in going into medicine or just in the history of medicine and/or media. It's helpful to know about these famous medical campaigns, many of which still appear in pop culture, and the class isn't too much work.
Yes
Yes, if they are interested already.

Definitely not a gut unless you know a lot about the history of media and medicine. The readings are pretty long and generally takes a few hours a week to get through. The midterm and final were pretty hard and graded harshly. Most people I talked to got a solid B/B- with very little feedback. The final is either harder and longer.
I would recommend this class to another student if they were looking to take a humanities class, but not if they lacked interest in history.
I would definitely recommend M&M to students with any sort of interest in medicine, the media, healthcare, etc.

I probably would not recommend this course to another student if they are interested in humanities or history. It seems to be a good history credit for non-history majors, however, I felt it was too surface level with very little analysis or deeper significance of what we were learning. There is a lot of good and interesting content, but I have taken much better history classes whilst here.
yes
yes, definitely interesting perspectives and relevant topics. I usually do not enjoy learning about history but I genuinely enjoyed going to lecture

This has been my favorite course that I have taken at Yale thus far. The material in this course is very interesting, not to mention taught in a unique way. Rather than telling the students about advertisements, the professors show them on the screen. I highly recommend this course!
Yes! Take this class if you are interested in media, medicine, or controversial topics in American history.
I do, you get to learn a lot, but be prepared to put in A LOT of work.
Absolutely! This class is by far my favorite class I have taken at Yale. Ive learned so much and the material is extremely interesting. Its not too much work, so its a nice 5th class.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student! One of my favorite courses at Yale so far!

Can you bear taking an HSHM course? Do you want a gut? Do you lack any sort of shame before you go to bed that you are wasting your parents' money on an intellectual farce of a course? If the answer to any of those questions is a no, do not take the course.
Yes because it gives you a glimpse of how we are spoon fed information through the media
If you're remotely interested in the topic, I believe you will enjoy the material. Just be prepared for the layout of the class.
Yes take it without a doubt
No.
Yes! A great HU credit for science majors. Interesting and not too much work.
Absolutely. Great all around course for any college student. Even for individuals not interested in medicine.

Yes! if you're interested in learning about how medicine has changed in the media throughout history, definitely take it. It's not difficult and talks about events/movements that we already know about, but just connects it to medicine. The assignments were a midterm, final, and final paper. For section you had to read readings and write a summary, but the readings were all short and very interesting.

I wouldn't really recommend this class unless you're interested in the subject matter. Lectures are pretty dry, and while the workload is low, it will be a drag to study for exams and write the paper.

Yes I would definietly recommend. The material is really interesting and the two professors do a pretty good job of sharing their knowledge. There is not that much work and there are so many readings taht if you just pick some of the shorter ones to do, you can still get expand you understanding without a huge committment. Work load is a midterms, weekly reading responses for sections, a final, and a ~8 page final paper.
Yes it is interesting
Most definitely.  This has been my favorite class at Yale.  It was easy to engage in and was fun to learn and study for.
Yes! Great 5th class or just class to learn about a super important topic and not worry too much about the work.
I would--it is very interesting for anyone who likes HSHM and how the media affects our perceptions on health.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in pursuing a career in medicine or healthcare. Learning about how the medical system worked in the past and about the medical controversies of the past really help illuminate patient-doctor dynamics that you wouldn't otherwise think about. As someone who wants to become a doctor, this class gave me a lot to think about in terms of how patients should be treated and how doctor-patient relationships can often be one-sided. In addition, learning about past medical abuses really puts the question of ethics into the forefront and its illuminating to see how many people at the time didn't view things like the Tuskegee studies as unethical.
Yes. I found it a manageable work load and the information was really interesting.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students. Most of the course content we discuss are very interesting; it was great tracing media's portrayal of medicine through time and seeing how this portrayal affected the public's perception of the medical institution.
Very interesting
Yes! Interesting course that gives a good overview of how media and public health go hand-in-hand.

I would recommend Media and Medicine to students interested in learning about medical history as it was affected by the media over the years. The workload is relatively low, but you learn a lot from the readings and from class. I recommend however doing alternative readings to support those given in class -- just to get a full picture of the time period (the first half of the semester we learned about medicine only as it related to white individuals)
Yes, if you are looking for a relatively low workload but interesting course.
Yes, it is a great course to understand the intersection of media and health.
A very relaxed class. The mixed media format was a refreshing change from the typical large lecture format where the professor is talking the whole time.
Never.
Yes, great humanities 5th credit and is actually pretty interesting.
Yeah it's a fun one for sure.
yes!! amazing information, lectures were a treat!
if you're interested
Yes. Good humanities. Great info. Would recommend to anyone who is interested in going into medicine or was generally interested in the media.
No, the material is superficial and you can never understand what they really expect of you on assignments and exams.

I would recommend this course to other students. The lectures and discussion sections introduced me to a side of American media that I had not previously recognized or appreciated. Each class provides the origins of different facets of health in this country. The course layout includes two classes each week, with the first one focusing on early 20th century history while second focuses on a modern day equivalent. This makes it easier to see and appreciate how history has shaped elements of health and well being around us.

I didn't really like this course until the very end. If you are good at and enjoy humanities courses, go for it, it's a pretty chill gut that gets interesting after a few weeks. If you aren't good at writing essays or following historical course content - maybe not.
Yes
No. Personally, I did not find the content as interesting as I thought I would, and the mandatory workload was a lot greater than necessary to do well in the class.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is very engaging and interesting.
Yes I would; it was a really interesting class and the essay is fun to write.

I would recommend this course to anyone! You don't need a strong background in medicine to enjoy this course and you learn so much about present day and past media campaigns, advertisements, drugs, movies, etc. The lectures are interesting - you will want to talk about them with your friends!

Highly highly recommend. It's one of those beautiful courses at Yale (Bioethics and Law is another one) where I felt like I had learned so much material that is a) actually relevant and useful in future endeavors and just as a member of society b) that I will retain after the course, AND I didn't have to put in too much work in order to acquire all that knowledge (the class just has one paper and a couple tests). Incredible fifth class, incredible class in general. Also probably a good one to Credit D because the lectures are great and there's not much work.

This is a great 5th class to take. The class covers the role of media in health movements beginning in the 1870s. This class reinforces the broad American historical timeline since the 1870s, and connects major events to the way the media decided to engage the public and portray the  medical discoveries/establishment. In particular, you discover how the use of media led to the perceived rise and fall of the glorification of the medical profession. The workload is super easy and includes weekly reading response (super short), midterm, final essay, and a final. The lectures and readings are super engaging. GO TO CLASS, because the slides don't really describe what was said in class. Overall low stress, enjoyable, and a lot of fun, general knowledge material.  For me, I enjoyed learning about what media campaigns were well received and effective, and which ones had inadvertent negative effects. It also forced me to question TV shows that I was previously a fan of, such as the Biggest Loser, that are pretty detrimental in spreading negative stigma about obesity. Recommend if looking for a fun, easy humanities.
The lecture material for the course was really interesting -- i'd encourage you to go to class. Your experience with the course can vary based on your section, so try to choose a TA you vibe with.
Id recommend this course to other students if theyre interested in film or media studies and medicine.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in public health/medicine/media or are looking for a low workload Hu credit.
I would because it is a light workload but you are learning about a relevant and interesting topic. It is engaging and opened my mind to different consequences of the media in shaping medicine.
I would recommend this course to another student, as it was engaging and interesting.
Yes it was very interesting
Grading is subjective and seems to be at random and depends almost solely at the TA
Yes just because of much we pay attention to media today
I would recommend this course. It was interesting and the professors and TAs were not too strict.
yes
Absolutely! Excellent lecturers, and really intriguing content that can be connected to modern day.
Good for those who are interested in studying a history of public health in the USA
I would absolutely recommend this course to any student seeking a so or hu credit.
Yes
Definitely, it's a really cool course, you'll definitely learn something.
I think students across all majors could learn a lot from this class. It's really interesting and also very relevant.
Yes! It's a super interesting course. I truly enjoyed going to every single lecture. If you're interested in medicine, I would highly recommend.

Yes! I loved every part of this class. It was relatively easy to do well in, the topics were engaging, and I felt there was a whole other part of American history I would've missed out on had I not taken this course.
Interesting course, low workload. Good fifth class, slam dunk Cr/D candidate.
I would recommend this class if you are interested in history, the history of medicine, media analysis, or just want an easy humanities class.
Yes, this course is engaging and has a low workload but is also very interesting. I learned a lot and it was surprisingly valuable, which was far more than I expected going in.

I would definitely recommend this course as it does a great job of pushing one out of their comfort zone regarding what they thought they knew about medicine and the medical field in general. The course can also be very eye-opening for some who may not have heard of some of the material that is covered in the course.
Yes
Yes
I would, found the class sincerely interesting.
Yes!
I would highly recommend this class to another student. The lectures are all very interesting and the workload is very manageable.
Ended up really enjoying this class. You only need to attend most lectures/sections and you'll be fine. Highly recommend if you're looking for a fun 5th/gut!

This is a great 3rd, 4th, or 5th course. You can't just show up to the midterm and final without going to class because a large portion of the midterm and final was based on media images that are shown during lecture/section. The class is pretty straightforward and it's interesting. It's not the best class I've taken at Yale, but it's a great elective.
Yes I would. I found the class really interesting and engaging
yes
yes, if you are interested in the subject
Yes, if you like history, medicine, and media.
Yes if they wanted to learn about the modern medicine and how it came to be and the history leading up to it.
Yes
Yes, but only if you are interested in learning pure history, with a sprinkle of modern tactics. The media is present and history, but it is not the focus so much as historical content in medicine.
Yes!!
No. Other classes are so much more interesting
Definitely - really interesting class and not too difficult.
Yes! it was very informative and I wouldn't have learnt about it otherwise
Yes!
Yes. It is a interesting but also relaxed course.
Yes I thought it was very interesting material
Yes, I thought that it was a very well structured course and I learned a lot.
Yes 100%

I would recommend this course to another student since the material makes you a more informed member of medicine whether that be a future physician or patient. The media/ image analysis skills that I developed in this course will be useful in other courses at Yale, another reason I suggest that other students take this course.

I would recommend this course because its a good intro level course to see if youre acrually interested in the history of science and medicine. The requirements of the course arent too serious at all and the workload is not that high compared to other Yale courses. As a result, its a good course to survey the field.
Yes I would I found it very interesting and it changed my perspective on medicine in general.

It was really interesting to see the role that media has had in shaping common conceptions that we have about the medical establishment, and how that has changed over time. I would recommend it to pretty much anyone as it's pretty relevant to our daily lives, and its good to be aware of how outside forces shape what we see and think. Both professors had pretty interesting lectures with lots of pictures and videos which was helpful in understanding the material. The workload wasn't bad, midterm final and paper, and the TAs work with you a lot in section to work through it. I did sort of feel like it was geared towards earlier classes, so taking it as a senior felt kind of easy (which can be good or bad).
Yes! So interesting for anyone!
Yes it was super interesting but not overwhelming.
I would recommend this course. It has a relatively low workload and it's interesting (if you like the topic).
I would. I feel the class is taught to inform us of how the media can and has influenced the public. It gives us the knowledge and understanding we need to look at things in an unbiased way.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the role of media in reinforcing or weakening the authority and prestige of the medical profession through film, posters, political cartoons, and television advertisements. However, please take note that the claim of "light reading" in the class syllabus is very misleading, as there are two entire Tyco course packets full of close to 100 readings. They are all great, but be prepared to read on average 50-75 pages a week.
I would recommend this course. It is a very interesting course with many topics and themes that keep the student engaged without having a heavy workload.
Yes, absolutely. I think it's relevant to any Yale student given the intersectional nature of the course.
Yes, I would recommend this class to any student, but especially if you are planning on entering a health-related field.
Yes, it is a great course that
Yes, it was very interesting and insightful
Yes, it was very engaging, interesting, and relevant to our understanding of medicine today
I would. I thought it was very interesting and I had never learned about some of the material before.
Yes, I was enlightened by what I learned in this course. I love being able to apply what I learned in lecture to phenomena and events that I see occur today.
Yes! Its really interesting and not too difficult even if you do not have a background in the area.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. As a large lecture, I think its appeal is the great lectures and interesting readings. I wouldn't recommend it as a course to improve your writing or get a lot of close attention, though.
Yes! very interesting course.
Yes but only if you actually do the work
